content.webTitle: Johnathan Thurston fully prepared to meet challenge of Leeds Rhinos

fields.headline: Johnathan Thurston fully prepared to meet challenge of Leeds Rhinos
fields.bodyText: The status of Johnathan Thurston as one of the all-time greats is reflected by his honour roll from the past decade. The 32-year-old has NRL championships, multiple State of Origin successes with Queensland, three Golden Boots for being the best player in the world and a World Cup triumph with Australia in 2013 to his name – but there is something missing for the North Queensland captain. Thurston is one of the sport’s most likeable characters – the way he conducts himself off the field is parallel to the way he acts on it – but he is not here this week to make friends: he is here to win the one trophy that has eluded him. English fans have been treated to rare glimpses of Thurston’s talents in an Australia shirt, but on Sunday he will play club rugby in this country for the first time, leading the Cowboys in their pursuit of a first World Club Challenge title as they take on the Super League champions, Leeds. The tournament has been considered somewhat of a pre-season friendly for some NRL clubs in the past, but the perception of the competition has changed in Australia. “I have prioritised this game, without doubt,” Thurston says. “It was a tough decision to pull out of the NRL All Stars game [which took place last week]; I’m very proud of my heritage and indigenous culture so it was difficult, but this was a box I really wanted to tick and I’ll give myself every opportunity of doing that by preparing with the boys. “This is our first time over here as a club, but we’ve come out pretty early to acclimatise, prepare and give ourselves every chance of winning. We’re taking it seriously. It would rank right up there with winning the Premiership if we do win: to be called the best team in the world has a nice ring to it.” While North Queensland have the same side that won last year’s Grand Final, Leeds’ preparations have been far from ideal. Not only have they lost their opening two Super League games – including a 56-12 humbling by Widnes that left them bottom of the table – but they are without some of their biggest names due to injury, including the captain, Danny McGuire, as they chase a record fourth world title. There is also the considerable loss of Jamie Peacock, Kylie Leului and Kevin Sinfield from their treble-winning team of 2015. Yet Thurston is still expecting a stern test at Headingley. He says: “I wouldn’t be reading too much into the way they’ve started their season. They are a quality club so we’re here to prepare as best we can, because we’ll need to. We’re not going to take them lightly. Whoever they put out on the field will do a great job for them. They’re a great club with great players.” The half-back pairings offer the best example of the differing preparations of the sides. Thurston will line up alongside Michael Morgan, the man whose back-of-the-hand pass in the NRL Grand Final created the Kyle Feldt try that took the game to extra time. Meanwhile, Leeds will field Liam Sutcliffe (21) and Jordan Lilley (19). Thurston knows little about the pair. “I’ve heard they’re pretty young and inexperienced, but in saying that they’ve got Rob Burrow who’s very experienced and he’ll get the boys around the park. He’s very sharp out of dummy-half or whatever position he plays.” As they look to start 2016 in a similar way to how 2015 finished, Thurston says the game is an important step for his emerging Cowboys side to take. “We haven’t spoken about creating a dynasty but like every other club in any competition we want to be in the big games,” he adds. “We’re coming up against a real tough outfit in Leeds who have been successful for many years, so we’re looking forward to the challenge.”
